text: [Music] [Music] [Music] [Music] in the last class we had looked at the furrow irrigation method and we had also mentioned that besides those three conventional methods which have become very popular over the last many many centuries the border irrigation basin irrigation and the foreign irrigation besides these two methods are these three methods there are some other methods which are variations of these methods they are also being used and some places where the situations weren't those methods should be applied either because of the the constraints the financial constraints are because the constraints of topography or the soil type or the soil that all those things put together they are let's discuss two of those methods which we had mentioned in the beginning these are contours dutch method and the other one is contour leavey method let's first look at in the case of contoured edge what type of layout we have and what it is suitable and with type of situations this is the figure of a contoured ditch irrigation method you can see here that as there are two ditches there is one ditch this is another ditch so what you have done is that you have laid the ditches some ditches the size of the ditch can also vary depending on how much is the stream size which is possible or which you want to use these ditches are laid on the contours and then you while irrigating the area you make the openings in the ditches and let the area be flooded so this is basically a method of wild flooding this is a method of wild flooding in which you have ditches which can be spaced about 20 to 25 meters and we go up to 100 meters the spacing between the ditches can be varying between 20 to 100 meters that means the area which will be covering from this end to the sand can be a a wide area in case you have the infiltration rates are lower if the infiltration rates are higher then you might restrict the weight between the ditches so that is that is up to the you have to look at many other conditions also the soil type and then the slope the slopes in this case is again the slope variation can be quite excessive you can use this this method of contoured edge on slopes which are as low as 0.15 or even higher slopes but again the restriction will be that what is the slope along with the soil type which is not creating any erosion problems and the stream size which you are going to use they are they are comparatively higher stream sizes you are flooding the areas you can afford to use the higher stream sizes if the areas are flatter areas if the areas are steeper areas you might reduce the stream size so in this method is not basically a method which is a very sophisticated method you are using this method because of the fact that you want to make use of the existing conditions and you don't want to indulge much expense which is involved in forming the area or grading the area so the adaptability if you look at where these methods from the adaptability point of view you will find this method to be quite useful when you are talking in terms of foothills those areas which are lying on the foothills which are having slight undulations but not the slopes are not very steep but the same time you cannot afford to form these areas or relay these areas because of the fact that the soil depth is quite shallow so if you try to reform these areas or you go in for the grading of these areas you will find that the soil the fertile soil will be lost you might be having a very small depth which you cannot manipulate you cannot you cannot grade that soil because of the loss in fertility and as such the the depth of soil available is very shallow then that is involving very low cost on those accounts because you don't need any in this case there is no land grading required the ditches are also unlined so there also you can save lot of expenses then the labor expense is also not very excessive because the places at which you have to make the the openings as is not a very skilled thing with slight amount of experience you will know that at what spacing because that will be a function of spread of the water up to which area the water can spread so it is not a very scientific method is only a method which may be used under some circumstances where you don't have any other possibility of using the other method because of various reasons which we have just discussed let's quickly go down to the next method of contour leave me which again is quite similar in terms of the previous method which you have discussed because in this case also you use this method where the situations or the conditions don't warrant any land grading or land shaping because of various reasons and in this method you are not using the ditches but you are using the natural slope which is available available in the area so if you look at this this is a strip this is a strip which is not a parallel strip as you have in the case of borders in the case of border irrigation you are trying to make the steps parallel so that you can have a very uniform flow over the strip in this case there is some the the slope may be in this direction there is a gentle slope so you have try to utilize that slope which is in this particular case the slope will be in this direction because you are supplying the water from some upstream end to the downstream end and this strip and this strip you have not you have tried to use the contours these are the natural contours which might be having some downslope because unless the slope is there you might find that the water might not move in a in the lateral direction and longitudinal direction so you have to have some slight slope otherwise the size of the stream will have to be very excessive and the slopes are less the lesser the slope to cover larger area you'll have to have excessive stream size but that can only happen if the soil type is as conducive to that higher stream sizes so in this case you have the ridges which are separating which are going parallel to each other not exactly parallel but they are going along the the strip and on this side you are having two ridges which are perpendicular one ridge here the other edge at this location so this channel can be used to collect the surplus water which may be used in the next step so this is again a method of flooding where you are not flooding in the same manner as you are doing in the ditch and dutch method where the water was flowing along the ditch in this case the water is flowing at some field channel which is at the upstream end so you release the water from there it moves into this and then the surplus amount is collected it might go to the next field so is normally used where you have the field to field flooding in areas where for example the delta areas where you don't have any problem of the amount of water available in our kaveri delta region we are using this method where you are letting the water flow from one area into another area and with the consequence that most of the time the water might be standing there so that is the reason that you are using the paddy the petty crop is quite popular in those areas because patty needs the quite a lot of water and in this method you can provide that water because the water is coming from one field going to the next field going to the next field and that continues and this method can also be used for other crops which are not very sensitive crops for example the grasses can be this method can be used the other top can be uh for the crops again you can use this method you might not have that continuous supply you might have intermittent supply because the further crops again they cannot sustain that longer inundation so the adaptability of this method again is quite similar that you are you can use it for those areas where you don't have any any availability of excess labor the labor costs are very less in this case the otherwise land farming cost can also be reduced by not grading the areas even if there is some problem in terms of the levels you might since the depth of water is quite excessive so the distribution might not be uniform but the same time and the distribution loss can be compensated by the the amount of expense which is safe so these methods are not a general purpose method they are specific purpose methods where you can you can justify these methods in some conditions under some situations where either the suitability or the economic conditions of the farmers are the type of crop which are growing they are the the major deciding factors so with that we will conclude the the methods which are surface irrigation methods as we have defined in the beginning we go down to the next class of irrigation methods which we were which we had started with along the surface irrigation method we had said the subsurface irrigation method and this category of irrigation method we are supplying water water is applied below the ground surface so this is the basic difference between the surface irrigation method and the subsurface irrigation method in the case of surface rehabilitation method we have seen that we are making use of the gravity flow but the water is traveling over the surface of the the soil on the ground whereas in the case of subsurface irrigation the water is not traveling over the surface of the ground but is travelling within the ground surface below the ground surface now what kind of method this can be if you just try to visualize you will find that the typical suppose this is your ground surface now if you want to make the waters because the root zone that we know there's the roots on depth and which we are interested in we want to supply moisture to the root zone that this area because the the plant root system is in this area and because of that fact this needs moisture in the case of subsurface irrigation there is a way out that the possible solutions are that you either provide that some sort of ditch you have a date where you control the water you have a ditch where you have this is the water level now this water level is under your control what will happen if you maintain this water level here and if the groundwater table is somewhere down below depending on what type of soil you're using what type of soil is prevailing there will be some flow from this area into this area some water will flow into the resonance again it will be a function of how much water will flow will be function of what is the wetness of the soil and what is the relative location of the groundwater table and the groundwater table is very low most of the water might go down some water might go into the lateral direction as we have seen in the case of furrow irrigation but this situation when you use the subsurface irrigation we are basically using the segregation when the groundwater table is already very is quite high you don't use this irrigation when the groundwater tables are very low because in that case most of the water which will be making available in the ditches because this water has to be made available artificially you have to bring this water from some supply source this source can be either the canal water or it can be the groundwater which you have pumped and put into the channel system it can be any any source so this the level which you have created here in the ditch and the level which is the groundwater table if the groundwater table is somewhere here you will find that after some time there will be some level stabilization if you keep on supplying this water there will be some flow from the ditch into this area and the water table might come up locally now this this rise in water table is within your control if you find let me put this here again that if i have a ditch which is along a ditch if i have this is the ditch now in this particular case by controlling the level of water if my previous water table was this is the water table which i have established after a long um after controlling this level for a long party period you'll find that this doesn't stabilize the water will keep on moving on this side and depending on the soil type the soil type is quite porous this might be achieved relatively in a quicker manner now if this is the the level here which i have attained it has become quite excessive i can reduce this level by removing water from the ditch this will come down initially it will be like this after some time it might become this and after some more time it will this will be achieved this fluctuation is what is in your control and that is what you do in the case of subsurface irrigation the design parameters which you have to look at when you design the subsurface irrigation are what should be the spacing between the ditches is that will decide up to what level the water table when you when you control these levels of water and the ditches how much time it will take for the water to drop down to the level desired level how much time how quickly it will do that because that is a function of the soil type what is the hydraulic conductivity of the soil as that will decide the movement of the water into soil so depending on the soil type you can design what should be the the spacing between the the ditches you can also design the other parameter will be what should the depth of the ridge that will give you the flexibility on up to what level you can control that the water depth then you can also decide on what should be the size of the ditch so these are some of the parameters which you'll design now this is one option available that you have the ditches if you want to choose another option which is quite a usual option you might replace these ditches with the circular pipes you have this instead of having ditches you can have underground pipes which are having perforations the water passes through these pipes and it gets it does the will be the depth up to which you have to lay down the pipe what will be the spacing between the the pipes and what size of the pipe has to be used these are some of the parameters which will be needed to design the system how the system should be laid out and that will be also a function of what type of crops you are utilizing these methods whether it's uh whether you're using the ditch or whether you're using the perforated pipe and a ground pipe for the subsurface irrigation in general you'll find that the suitability of this method is quite is not used at many many places there are a
